Award.AwardTitle: Statistical Inference for Tree Models with Strong Hierarchical Autocorrelation
Award.AbstractNarration:
Models with tree-structured, hierarchical autocorrelation are used when sampling units are related to each other. Their inheritance history is modeled by a tree, which is used to parametrize the residual correlation structure among observations. The project will develop an asymptotic theory for these autocorrelation models, arising from an Ornstein-Uhlenbeck process along the tree. As the number of tips in the tree grows indefinitely, the investigators will determine which parameters are microergodic and which parameters are not. The asymptotic consistency and the rate of convergence of the maximum likelihood estimator are expected to vary importantly depending on the microergodicity of the parameter and on topological properties of the tree. Analogies will be built between this asymptotic framework and the infill asymptotic framework in spatial statistics, when observations are collected on a dense set of locations within a bounded region of space. The project will refine the concept of effective sample size for hierarchically autocorrelated data and study optimal sampling designs. This work will provide important steps toward developing appropriate model selection tools for the detection of possibly many Ornstein-Uhlenbeck selection regimes, with a large number of model parameters compared to the sample size.

Tree models with hierarchical autocorrelation arose first in evolutionary biology and ecology, with the comparison of biological species. These models are now used in many other areas, ranging from the study of rapidly evolving viruses to the study of human language evolution. The Ornstein-Uhlenbeck model is used to detect selection as opposed to neutral evolution, to discover changes in selective regime and to determine driving factors of selection. The project will provide a unified statistical asymptotic framework for these models and will inform best practices for empirical studies. Computational tools will be broadly disseminated, and opportunities will be provided for training at the interface between statistics and biology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

In this project, we studied the behavior of statistical methods that are used by biologists to learn about the past history of species from living species that we can observed today. These methods are used to learn how natural selection on morphological characters acted in the past, to give the diversity of species we see today. We theoretically showed what are the limits of what we can learn about the past from the present: we proved which aspects (or statistical parameters) of morphological evolution can be learned from the present, and which aspects cannot, and under what conditions. These conditions depend on how fast new species were formed, and on how strong the pressure of natural selection was. We also showed why some traditional methods that work well for other statistical problems actually break down for very large studies of past morphological evolution. To remedy these problems, we developed a new method adapted to evolutionary tree models. One statistical challenge is the correlation between closely related species. Our method performs well to detect past changes in the natural selection process, even though there is a very large number of scenarios to consider and to test. For example, these methods can detect if changes in selection pressure on the morphology of lizard species happened at the same time as changes in habitat that these lizard species experienced in the past. We developed a software package to conduct these analyzes, which is orders of magnitude faster than previously available software. Our software enables biologists to analyzes data sets with thousands of species, something that was not possible before, and that opens new possibilities for "big data" analyses of species diversity. Our software is made available freely and open source.

Broader Impacts

The methods we developed are bringing statistical rigor to studies of biological diversity and of natural selection on morphological evolution. These rigorous methods are applicable to many groups of organisms, and have already been applied by many other researchers to their own scientific questions. We implemented these methods in software that is made freely available to the research community. Our software is open-source, to empower others to further improve on our methods. The project contributed to the training of 3 graduate and undergraduate students, who gained expertise in all three of these areas: statistics, computing, and biology. This project helped develop a workforce eager and able to cross discipline boundaries and to deal with big data in their future workplace.
